intent: Microscope calibration before any biology: illumination/flat-field, channel registration, focus map, PSF-ish checks, camera noise/fixed-pattern, vignetting, crosstalk

notes: This plate is run BEFORE the measurement-rule plate.
Goal is to learn the microscope's behavior: illumination non-uniformity, focus drift, chromatic shift, bleed-through, and repeatability.
All wells are either dye solutions (flat-field), multicolor beads (registration), dark wells (camera baseline), or blanks.

DARK.description: Imaging buffer or PBS only. Used to measure camera offset, dark current proxy, and background.

BLANK.description: No liquid (if permitted) or minimal buffer. Used to detect dust, autofluorescence, and plate plastic artifacts.

FLATFIELD_DYE_LOW.description: Uniform fluorescent dye (or premix) at low intensity. Used for flat-field + linearity checks without saturation.

FLATFIELD_DYE_HIGH.description: Uniform fluorescent dye (or premix) at higher intensity. Used to check saturation, shading correction stability, and exposure robustness.

MULTICOLOR_BEADS_SPARSE.description: Sparse multicolor beads (e.g., TetraSpeck-like). Used for chromatic registration, PSF-ish spot shape, and focus sensitivity.

MULTICOLOR_BEADS_DENSE.description: Denser beads. Used for repeatability, field curvature hints, and robust registration stats.

FOCUS_BEADS.description: Beads optimized for autofocus (bright, stable). Used to map focus performance and field curvature.

principles: Put flat-field dye everywhere (including edges) to map illumination and vignetting.
Put beads in a spatially distributed pattern to measure chromatic shifts across the field.
Include repeated tiles to estimate local repeatability (same material, same settings).
Include dark wells to measure camera baseline and background drift.

default_assignment.notes: Most wells are flat-field dye low by default

dark_wells.notes: Camera baseline/background across corners and mid-edges

blank_wells.notes: Optional. If your plate handling hates empty wells, fill with DARK instead.

flatfield_high.notes: Central band for high-intensity flat-field and exposure stress

multicolor_beads_sparse.notes: Spatially distributed sparse beads for chromatic registration across plate

multicolor_beads_dense.notes: Denser bead stats for robust registration and field-dependent effects

focus_beads_map.notes: Grid to characterize autofocus performance and field curvature

repeatability_tiles.purpose: Estimate local repeatability and detect small focus/illumination drifts

acquire: Use the exact objective, filters, exposures, binning, and autofocus mode you will use for Cell Painting.
Acquire at least 2 fields per well for flat-field wells; more if you want a good illumination map.
For bead wells, capture enough beads per field to estimate shift vectors per channel (sparse) and robust stats (dense).
Include at least one full-plate pass twice (same day) to quantify repeatability.
compute: Per-channel flat-field image (illumination profile) and shading correction.
Per-channel chromatic registration map (shift vectors across the field).
Focus success rate and best-focus z distribution across the plate.
Background and camera offset estimates from DARK wells.
Bleed-through / crosstalk estimates from single-channel dominance (if your dye/bead set allows).
pass_fail: Flat-field correction reduces intensity CV across the plate by a large factor (your threshold).
Registration errors are below your pixel threshold across the field.
Autofocus succeeds at high rate across the plate and does not systematically fail on edges.
No catastrophic hot pixels, striping, or field-dependent artifacts remain unmodeled.

why: Once illumination + registration + focus are characterized, the next plate can attribute remaining structure to workflow + biology rather than optics.

reference.note: This microscope calibration plate is intended as the step immediately before the rules-of-world plate.
